name: Infinite Sums
description:
Introduction

As you go about your day in college, you spot your **crush** in the mathematics department doing some work on her master's thesis. Shyly, you approach her and ask what she is doing. > I'm trying to solve this infinite series, but I can't figure out a way to generalize it for other values of ```n```. Here, take a look: ```math f(n) = \sum_{k = 1}^{\infty} \frac {k^{n}}{2^{k}} ``` > If only someone knew a way to compute its higher-order terms, it would be extremely helpful to get to know its growth rate, even if experimentally. Spotting an opportunity to impress her, you decide to lend a helping hand in the matter. *"Don't fret, m'lady, I have what it takes to take on such a challenge,"*Â  you say in the creepiest and most incel way possible. > Thanks, I guess... After creeping out your crush into accepting your help, you confidently walk away to tackle the matter, hearing a sigh of relief as you leave...

Task

Given an integer ```n``` between ```0``` and ```800``` as input, write a function ```sequence``` that computes the *nth* term of the sequence defined by: ```math f(n) = \sum_{k = 1}^{\infty} \frac {k^{n}}{2^{k}} ``` Hint: All of its values are integers.

Anti Cheat

In order to prevent one from hardcoding all the values, there is a character cap set at ```1000``` characters. Unless you're trying to cheese this kata, you really shouldn't worry about this limit, as 1 thousand characters is way more than enough to solve it.

Examples

```python sequence(0) -> 1 sequence(1) -> 2 sequence(2) -> 6 ```
